results.title: Map of the human heart (D)
results.creator_credit: Vincent Ward Films, Tim Bevan and Vincent Ward
results.brief_description: New Zealander Vincent Ward’s third film is an immensely ambitious and audacious love story spanning 30 years and two continents. Much of it is set and filmed above the Arctic Circle in northern Canada, providing breathtaking scenery. Some journeys have no map to guide them. This is an epic voyage from a kingdom of ice to a world on fire. It is the magical story of Avik and Albertine and a love that survived decades, impossible distances and the ravages of war.

results.title: Map makers
results.creator_credit: Australia. Army. Directorate of Public Relations
results.brief_description: This film shows the work carried out by the members of the Royal Australian Survey Corps in South Vietnam, Sumatra, North Western Australia and Bendigo in Victoria in the production of various types of maps.

results.title: Maoriland movielogues. No. 12
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items including: 1. Tall timbers - Kauri forest, north Auckland, shows a 1200 year old tree and a sap gatherer climbing 52 feet up. 2. Dunedin - New Zealand’s Scottish city. Shows street scenes including trams and a cable car; domestic architecture and the Johnson quadruplets. 3. Ski land - action shots and ski instruction in one of New Zealand’s national parks. 4. Daffodil - springtime in central Otago. 5. Fiordland - Milford Sound including Sutherland Falls and memorial to explorer Clinton MacKinnon.

results.title: Maoriland movielogues. No. 10
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items: 1.Rotorua Spa, New Zealand’s thermal spa. Scenes at the Sanatorium and Maori children diving for pennies. 2. Maoriland medley - in old New Zealand. To the accompaniment of Maori singing, sports, crafts and dancing are shown. 3. Rakiura, Stewart Island, New Zealand. Scenes and games on the holiday island. 4. Oddities - Moeraki Boulders, New Zealand. 5. Flying high over New Zealand’s southern alps. A flight of the RNZAF leaves Wighan Airfield, Christchurch for a flight over the Alps.

results.title: Maori village: a concert rehearsal near Rotarua
results.brief_description: Shows life in a typical Maori village; various customs of the Maoris; washing clothes in the hot pools; children at play; traditional costumes; concert party rehearse songs and dances; thermal activity; geysers and boiling springs.

results.title: Maori moods and melodies
results.creator_credit: Neuline Film Productions, New Zealand. Government Tourist Bureau and Robert Steele
results.brief_description: New Zealand, home of the Maori people; steaming geysers, bubbling mud and dense forests; snow-lined mountains and turbulent water falls; the fine art of carving; and dancing.

results.title: Maori legends of New Zealand
results.creator_credit: New Zealand National Film Unit, Conon Fraser, Martin Townsend and Nicki Dennis
results.brief_description: Seven animated short stories based on the traditional spirit world of the Maori. 1. Pania of the reef 2. Maui catches the sun 3. Kuhukura’s net 4. Te hautaewa’s run 5. Rata and the canoe 6. Timirau’s pet whale 7. Rau Tapu’s magic feather. The seven programs would be best viewed separately as seven in a row is a bit of an overkill that causes dulling of the appreciation of the content.
results.creator_credit_for_label: New Zealand National Film Unit, Conon Fraser, Martin Townsend and Nicki Dennis

results.title: Maori arts and culture. No. 1. Carving and decoration
results.creator_credit: New Zealand National Film Unit, Geoffrey Scott, Cyril Morton and Ronald Bowie
results.brief_description: Explains how the traditional Maori art of carving has been revived in New Zealand. Emphasises the creation of new forms in this ancient art by the use of modern materials and machines. Filmed at the Artifacts Dominion Museum, New Zealand.

results.title: Maori
results.creator_credit: New Zealand. Ministry of Foreign Affairs
results.brief_description: Discusses the Maori population in New Zealand and describes their customs, traditions and spiritual beliefs. Also makes reference to employment opportunities as well as social problems, experienced by Maoris. Contrasts modern New Zealand society with traditional Maori culture.

results.title: Mao: organised chaos
results.creator_credit: Don Thompson, Sam Summerlin, Pat Ferns, New York Times Productions and Nielsen-Ferns
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Leaders of the twentieth century: portraits of power”.
Second in a two part film on Mao Tse-tung. Looks at Mao and his regime from the proclamation of the People’s Republic of China on 1st October 1949, to his death in 1976. Follows the cultural revolution; the elimination of Mao’s enemies; Mao’s visit to Moscow; the Korean War; Chiang’s regime; and Nixon’s visit to China. Narrated by Henry Fonda. Suitable for upper secondary level.
